Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Single-Molecule Spectroscopy as a Mechanistic Tool for Studying Catalyst Reaction Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-B Program of the Division of Chemistry, will enable Professor Randall H. Goldsmith of the University of Wisconsin Madison to develop and apply tools that enable the observation of unsynchronized chemical dynamics of individual molecular catalysts under turnover conditions. These methods will enable determination of the kinetics of formation and depletion of transient intermediates and temporal fluctuations of catalyst behavior, including shifting rate constants and enantioselectivity. The impact of these microscopic behaviors on bulk reaction dynamics will be explored. Measurements will be made via time-resolved fluorescence microscopy. Fluorophore design, chemical synthesis, and fabrication and deployment of plasmonic nanostructures are critical elements of this approach. Taken together, these activities will allow determination of a chronology of the molecular dynamics of catalysis that will add new insights on reaction mechanism and guide strategies for future catalyst development.

Underneath all macroscopic observations that humans can make in everyday life is a churning, vibrant, and dynamic world at the microscopic level of single molecules. By making measurements on single molecules, this proposal endeavors to remove the disconnect between the macro- and micro-world for two purposes. First, the chaotic nature of single molecules hides molecular behavior that has important consequences for industrially useful chemical reactions. Revealing the molecular dynamics of individual catalyst molecules, molecules that enable challenging chemical reactions, will allow greater understanding of their mode of operation, leading the way to the design of new and more effective catalysts and cheaper and "greener" chemistry. Second, removing this disconnect has important consequences for chemical education, as understanding chemical behavior on the macro-scale flows naturally from understanding chemistry at the micro-scale. Few educational experiments exist that can allow students and non-scientists to truly "see" single molecules. This proposal contains a closely integrated outreach activity to build a robust and portable microscope that will allow users to see single molecules with the naked eye. This educational tool will be built and used for new chemical education initiatives in museums and schools, including those with large components of students under-represented in science and technology careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The action of molecular catalysts comprises multiple microscopic kinetic steps whose nature is of central importance in determining catalyst activity and selectivity.  Single-molecule microscopy enables the direct examination of these steps, including elucidation of molecule-to-molecule variability. This project supported the development of tools to study these steps, including designer molecules where fluorescence can be linked to a chemical process or state of interest, and nanophotonic tools to access more relevant chemical conditions.   

We synthesized the fluorescent catalysts in Figure 1A. Molecule 4 was unexpectedly as bright an emitter as 2, despite possessing four BODIPY chromophores.  We investigated the brightness scaling laws empirically and via numerical simulation in a paper in J. Phys. Chem. C.

We explored molecule 3 as a single-molecule label and found it exhibited highly advantageous properties. Armed with this enabling fluorophore, we performed the first combined investigation of the initiation dynamics of an operational palladium cross-coupling catalyst at the bulk and single-molecule levels, including under turn-over conditions.  Bulk initiation was monitored via NMR, while the loss of fluorescence due to ligand dissociation after base attack at the metal center, the first step of initiation, was used as a proxy for initiation at the single-molecule level. Kinetics revealed highly heterogeneous behavior indicative of diverse catalyst population, Figure 1B. We modeled this behavior and identified specific microscopic steps where chemical variability must exist in order to yield observed behavior and showed how the surface is a natural source of this variability. Our investigation constitutes the first direct observation of the effect of the molecular catalyst structural heterogeneity on the catalyst dynamics. This work was published in J. Am. Chem. Soc. and spotlighted. In a paper in Langmuir, we used similar methodology to examine kinetics of surface anchor destruction and showed that the optimal means of stabilizing surface coatings on glass is to sterically block reactive sites at the surface.  

We developed new surface support chemistries capable of resisting this surface anchor destruction including the first use of tetrazine-norbornene cycloaddition click chemistry to support a catalyst, in a paper in Molec. Catal., where it received an editor’s choice designation.

A critical barrier to further advance is concentration. Single-molecule fluorescence microscopy is typically employed at nanomolar concentrations, while relevant conditions for molecular catalyst are millimolar and greater.  Using cyclic-nucleotide binding-domains as a models, we have showed how the combination of nanophotonic Zero Mode Waveguides and Förster Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET) can increase the concentration range over which single-molecule measurements can be applied to record heights, up to millimolar concentrations, Figure 1C, over 100 times higher than the previous record.  This is a tremendous enabling technology, and was published in Angew. Chemie.        

A final project was run almost entirely by undergraduates.  Lithium ion batteries (LIB’s) are desirable energy storage devices due to their high energy and power densities but experience power fade due to materials issues that are best addressed with new analytical approaches.  We developed a new method for visualized of flow of lithium ions in batteries. We synthesized new HPBO (2-(2-hydroxyphenyl)benzoxazole) chemical markers that fluoresce in the presence of lithium. These markers describe lithium ion position and flow by exploiting the high time and spatial resolution of fluorescence microscopy, Figure 1D. Three undergraduates synthesized the molecules, and two undergraduates were responsible for the microscopy.  This story was published in ACS Sensors with two undergraduate students as co-first authors. The paper was highlighed in Chemical and Engineering News.

Supported students and the PI participated in activities aimed at increasing public engagement with science and broadening participation.  One major activity was development of science modules with the rural summer camp science run with the Wisconsin Institute for Discovery. In post-activity assessments, 90% of the participants rated the experience Excellent (50%) or Good (40%). In 2016, one of these students (from Tomah high school in central Wisconsin, population: 9,093) was chosen to present their discussion of our single-molecule module at the Wisconsin Science Festival’s “Big Ideas Amazing Students” program, which provides an opportunity for participants from around the state to interact with government leaders at the State Capitol. Other activities included lectures delivered to local AP chemistry teachers, help running the Wisconsin Regional Science Bowl, contribution to the PEOPLE (Pre-college Enrichment Opportunity Program for Learning Excellence) program where students taught or helped prepare science lessons for low-income or STEM under-represented highschool students, and production of a Blue Sky science video on the size of molecules in collaboration with the Morgridge Institute (https://morgridge.org/blue-sky/how-many-molecules-are-in-a-cubic-inch/).

Two graduate students received their PhD with support from this project.
